data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description: Knee Deep’s Bourbon Barrel Aged Imperial Stout is a smooth tasting brew that has big malt flavors and plenty of bitterness which creates a well-balanced, bourbon flavored beer.  The barrel aging process gives this beer a spicy, vanilla character with a pleasant and warming finish.

available.name: Year Round
available.description: Available year round as a staple beer.

style.name: American-Style Imperial Stout
style.description: Black in color, American-style imperial stouts typically have a high alcohol content. Generally characterized as very robust. The extremely rich malty flavor and aroma are balanced with assertive hopping and fruity-ester characteristics. Bitterness should be moderately high to very high and balanced with full sweet malt character. Roasted malt astringency and bitterness can be moderately perceived but should not overwhelm the overall character. Hop aroma is usually moderately-high to overwhelmingly hop-floral, -citrus or -herbal. Diacetyl (butterscotch) levels should be absent.

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description: Blacker than night, stouter than stout is our Imperial Stout. Brewed with a lot of malt & a touch of honey, Imperial Stout is rich & robust with deep, deep notes of dark chocolate & espresso.

available.name: Seasonal
available.description: Available at the same time of year, every year.

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description: Dark and thick like your favorite dessert with a bonus.  Highly roasted malted barley, and plenty of it, gives the beer uncommon richness and smoky, roasty depth...kinda like a hydraulic sandwich in a glass

available.name: Year Round
available.description: Available year round as a staple beer.

style.name: American-Style Stout
style.description: Initial low to medium malt sweetness with a degree of caramel, chocolate and/or roasted coffee flavor with a distinctive dryroasted bitterness in the finish. Coffee-like roasted barley and roasted malt aromas are prominent. Some slight roasted malt acidity is permissible and a medium- to full-bodied mouthfeel is appropriate. Hop bitterness may be moderate to high. Hop aroma and flavor is moderate to high, often with American citrus-type and/or resiny hop character. The perception of fruity esters is low. Roasted malt/barley astringency may be low but not excessive. Diacetyl (butterscotch) should be negligible or not perceived. Head retention is excellent.

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description: This massive Stout pours a mahogany black with a thick, brown head. The aroma is all chocolate roasted malt. The aroma is all chocolate and toasted malt. The first wave of flavor embraces anise and dark, bitter chocolate but opens up to include coffee, smoke and rich sweet malt. The alcohol strength warms this beer as it goes down your throat.
data.foodPairings: Long-aged cheeses and dark chocolate desserts.

style.name: American-Style Imperial Stout
style.description: Black in color, American-style imperial stouts typically have a high alcohol content. Generally characterized as very robust. The extremely rich malty flavor and aroma are balanced with assertive hopping and fruity-ester characteristics. Bitterness should be moderately high to very high and balanced with full sweet malt character. data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description:
A dark-as-night Imperial stout dominated up front by a bold roasted malt flavor, which reveals hints of caramel, coffee and chocolate, while a subtle hop bitterness works in concert to reveal a dry, warming finish. On the nose, an earthy, peat smoke aroma accompanies the rich malt profile

We've teamed up with Vermont artist Tom Cullins, whose bold, beautiful work adorns the bottle label. Cullins' dynamic use of color and space provides a warming visual that echoes the structured chaos of the malts and hops that create this dynamic brew. 

Available November 2014 - February 2015

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description: Like India Pale Ale, the classic Imperial Stouts were originally brewed with high levels of alcohol and hops to withstand the rigors of a long sea journey, not to India but to Imperial Russia and the Baltic States. Our version is an over-the-top riff on the style, with a huge grain bill featuring several kinds of malted barley, wheat, rye, oats, and spelt. Robust grain and coffee flavors are counterbalanced by date and plum notes from the Belgian yeast. To add extra complexity and depth, this Imperial Stout is made up of a blend of freshly brewed beer and several barrel-aged beers, carefully balanced. Za Vas!

style.name: Specialty Stouts
style.description: See British Origin American-Style Imperial Porter Imperial porters are very dark brown to black in color. No roast barley or strong burnt/astringent black malt character should be perceived. Medium malt, caramel and cocoa-like sweetness should be in harmony with medium-low to medium hop bitterness. This is a full bodied beer. Ale-like fruity esters should be evident but not overpowering and compliment malt derived sweetness and hop character. Hop flavor and aroma may vary from being low to medium-high. Diacetyl (butterscotch) levels should be absent.

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description:
A few times a year, we will cut Dan loose to brew whatever he chooses, uncensored, uncut, unplugged. Always handcrafted, this beer is brewed for the adventurous soul. This is a very limited edition and we make no promises to ever brew this style again. 

Fourth in our series this is Dan's "Unplugged Imperial Stout." This beer is handcrafted for you with the same care that English brewers used when they brewed Imperial Stouts for the Russian Royal Family. This is a strong beer brewed with lots of black barley. Back home that makes this beer an excellent candidate for lying down in your beer cellars.

style.name: American-Style Stout
style.description: Initial low to medium malt sweetness with a degree of caramel, chocolate and/or roasted coffee flavor with a distinctive dryroasted bitterness in the finish. Coffee-like roasted barley and roasted malt aromas are prominent. Some slight roasted malt acidity is permissible and a medium- to full-bodied mouthfeel is appropriate. Hop bitterness may be moderate to high. Hop aroma and flavor is moderate to high, often with American citrus-type and/or resiny hop character. The perception of fruity esters is low. Roasted malt/barley astringency may be low but not excessive. Diacetyl (butterscotch) should be negligible or not perceived. Head retention is excellent.

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description: Salted Butter Caramel Milk Imperial Stout

style.name: Sweet or Cream Stout
style.description: Sweet stouts, also referred to as cream stouts, have less roasted bitter flavor and a full-bodied mouthfeel. The style can be given more body with milk sugar (lactose) before bottling. Malt sweetness, chocolate, and caramel flavor should dominate the flavor profile and contribute to the aroma. Hops should balance and suppress some of the sweetness without contributing apparent flavor or aroma. The overall impression should be sweet and full-bodied.

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description: This batch of Imperial Stout is much evolved from gyle 100 (which was released late last year), and is bold, rich, and luscious. It marks the start of what we hope will become a great foundation for additions of cacao, coffee, spices, and more over subsequent brews this year.

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description: A big roasty imperial stout and a test batch for one of our future Double Black Diamond Series beers. Look for notes of coffee, chocolate and roasted malt in this nicely balanced Russian Imperial Stout.

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description: You don’t have to be a member of the court of Catherine II to enjoy this rich full bodied stout. Black and impenetrable to light, loaded with roasted barley, chocolate, dark fruit and bittersweet notes

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description:
An extremely black beer with massive roasted malt character balanced with assertive hopping from Northwest Chinook hops, fruity esters and a sinister alcohol content.

Silver Medal - North American Beer Awards - 2005 & 2004 
Gold Medal - North American Beer Awards - 2004

A traditional unfiltered Russian Imperial Stout.
A variety of intensely roasted malts & the aggressive use of hops temper the pleasant sweetness of the beer.

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description: Aged in our port barrels for six months - the result is a smooth dark beer full of aromas of dark chocolate, caramel and vanilla. Hints of raisins, cherries and smoke picked up from the barrel make this a robust but smooth stout.

style.name: Wood- and Barrel-Aged Beer
style.description: A wood- or barrel-aged beer is any lager, ale or hybrid beer, either a traditional style or a unique experimental beer that has been aged for a period of time in a wooden barrel or in contact with wood. This beer is aged with the intention of imparting the particularly unique character of the wood and/or what has previously been in the barrel. New wood character can be characterized as a complex blend of vanillin and/or other unique wood character, but wood aged is not necessarily synonymous with imparting wood-flavors. Used sherry, rum, bourbon, scotch, port, wine and other barrels are often used, imparting complexity and uniqueness to beer. Ultimately a balance of flavor, aroma and mouthfeel are sought with the marriage of new beer with wood and/or barrel flavors. Beers in this style may or may not have Brettanomyces character. Brewers when entering this category should specify type of barrel and/or wood used and any other special treatment or ingredients used. Competition managers may create style subcategories to differentiate between high alcohol and low alcohol beers and very dark and lighter colored beer as well as for fruit beers and non-fruit beers. Competitions may develop guidelines requesting brewers to specify what kind of wood (new or used oak, other wood varieties) and/or barrel (whiskey, port, sherry, wine, etc.) was used in the process. The brewer may be asked to explain the special nature (wood used, base beer style(s) and achieved character) of the beer.

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description: Imperial Stout is a powerful and full-bodied beer, brewed with several roasted malt types and matured with oak to round out the taste of the beer and give even more body. Imperial Stout has a soft carbonation, that gives a beautiful cream-colored foam and a well balanced flavor and mouthfeel. You will be able to taste notes of coffee, bitter chocolate, oak and vanilla. Serve Imperial Stout with game, strong cheese or chocolate desserts.
data.foodPairings: Serve Imperial Stout with game, strong cheese or chocolate desserts.

available.name: Year Round
available.description: Available year round as a staple beer.

style.name: British-Style Imperial Stout
style.description: Dark copper to very dark brown, British-style imperial stouts typically have high alcohol content. The extremely rich malty flavor (often characterized as toffee-like or caramel-like) and aroma are balanced with medium hopping and high fruity-ester characteristics. Bitterness should be moderate and balanced with sweet malt character. The bitterness may be higher in the darker versions. Roasted malt astringency is very low or absent. Bitterness should not overwhelm the overall character. Hop aroma can be subtle to moderately hop-floral, -citrus or -herbal. Diacetyl (butterscotch) levels should be absent.

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description: This beer pours a deep, dark brown with a light tan head. Aroma is malty, roasty with coffee notes and some very light aroma hop. It has a roasted coffee and chocolate taste with a sweet finish.

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description: Aged for one year, this brew is a hybrid between a Russian style Imperial Stout and an American Stout. This unique lager is jet black, smooth and tasty. The bittering hops offset the smooth sweetness of the roasted malt. A delicious after dinner beer, best enjoyed with friends. A perfect way to celebrate the beginning of the new year. Na Zdorovie!

data.description: Bottled Imperial Stout (9.3% alc/vol) We used Chocolate, Roasted, and Black malts making this a very thick beer. We decided to wax the tops of the bottles, meaning that they will age well.

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description: A fine companion to end a meal or relax in front of the hearth with, this robust ale will cellar well for years. Brewed with ten varieties of malted barley this stout is extremely smooth, complex and rich in body. We recommend serving at cellar temperature. Sit back and enjoy its richness and complexity, your about to drink the ultimate winter warmer.

The extremely rich malty flavor and aroma are balanced with assertive hopping and fruity-ester characteristics. Bitterness should be moderately high to very high and balanced with full sweet malt character. Roasted malt astringency and bitterness can be moderately perceived but should not overwhelm the overall character. Hop aroma is usually moderately-high to overwhelmingly hop-floral, -citrus or -herbal. Diacetyl (butterscotch) levels should be absent.

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description: A big, malty beer with lots of roasted malt character to aid the hop bitterness in balancing the finish.

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description: Aged for one year, this brew is a hybrid between a Russian style Imperial Stout and an American Stout. This unique lager is jet black, smooth and tasty. The bittering hops offset the smooth sweetness of the roasted malt. A delicious after dinner beer, best enjoyed with friends. A perfect way to celebrate the beginning of the new year. Na Zdorovie!

data.name: IMPERIAL STOUT
data.description:
This beer pours a deep, dark brown with a light tan head. Aroma is malty, roasty with coffee notes and some very light aroma hop. It has a roasted coffee and chocolate taste with a sweet finish.
 Silver medal winner 2012 New Mexico state fair.

style.name: American-Style Imperial Stout

style.name: American-Style Stout
style.description: Initial low to medium malt sweetness with a degree of caramel, chocolate and/or roasted coffee flavor with a distinctive dryroasted bitterness in the finish. Coffee-like roasted barley and roasted malt aromas are prominent. Some slight roasted malt acidity is permissible and a medium- to full-bodied mouthfeel is appropriate. Hop bitterness may be moderate to high. Hop aroma and flavor is moderate to high, often with American citrus-type and/or resiny hop character. The perception of fruity esters is low. Roasted malt/barley astringency may be low but not excessive. Diacetyl (butterscotch) should be negligible or not perceived. Head retention is excellent.

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description:
Dark, rich, intense and complex, our Imperial Stout is a force to be respected and savored. Originally brewed in Britain for export to Russia – and said to have been favored by Catherine the Great – Imperial Stout warms with a huge malt character. Each batch of this, our biggest “standard” beer, boasts over 2,000 pounds of malt and massive amounts of domestic whole hops.
Malts: Domestic Two Row Pale, Chocolate, Black Malt, Black Barley, and Brown Sugar Hops: Chinook

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description: Big, boozy, and viscous. Technically an oatmeal stout, this monster of a beer only gets better as it ages. Aging in whiskey barrels lends whiskey, vanilla, and oak to the finish.

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description: Created in the 18th Century by British brewers for the kinda scary Czars of Russia, the Imperial Stout was designed to be dark, strong, and hardy enough to handle the long and perilous voyage across the Baltic Sea. And you do not want to disappoint the Czars of Russia. Our version is made to stand the test of time, too, featuring rich flavors of chocolate, toffee, coffee, currant, and vanilla. Budem zdorovy!

style.name: British-Style Imperial Stout
style.description: Dark copper to very dark brown, British-style imperial stouts typically have high alcohol content. The extremely rich malty flavor (often characterized as toffee-like or caramel-like) and aroma are balanced with medium hopping and high fruity-ester characteristics. Bitterness should be moderate and balanced with sweet malt character. The bitterness may be higher in the darker versions. Roasted malt astringency is very low or absent. Bitterness should not overwhelm the overall character. Hop aroma can be subtle to moderately hop-floral, -citrus or -herbal. Diacetyl (butterscotch) levels should be absent.

data.name: Imperial Stout
data.description:
Aarhus Brewery Stout was inspired by the English Imperial Stout. Imperial Stout is the beer was originally developed for the Tsar's court in St. Petersburg. Petersburg. In the 1800s, this beer very popular. The beer bryggedes in England and sailed to Russia. In order to withstand the long journey was done beer extra strong compared to the Stout, sold in England. The beer was drained often champagne bottles.

The high alcohol content of 8% is to ensure the durability of the black beer. There used unrefined cane sugar from Mauritius as extra flavoring. Most English ales are brewed with unrefined cane sugar. By using unrefined sugar, you get tasting notes from cane sugar in the finished beer. The color is in the bright end of the scale. On the other hand, there is no added caramel color in this Stout!

 The taste of Aarhus Brewery Stout is thick and bold. Although it is a strong beer, it is not the hops that are dominant. This makes it easier to access than many other black beer. There is also a slight sweetness from cane sugar that is balanced with the hops. In time, hop bitterness subside, and the sweetness will dominate.

The young Stout will be a good companion to a piece of dark meat or a heavy casserole. It will certainly be obvious to drink for Christmas War or pork roast. Danish Yule developed over centuries, where we always have been drinking beer. Therefore suitable beer is just better to Danish cuisine.

Aarhus Brewery Stout will also be an excellent companion for all cheeses. Try to serve bread with cheese. Bread and Stouten will lift and compliment the cheeses.

Serving temperature of Aarhus Brewery Stout allowed to be about 10 degrees. It does not matter that the further warmed in the glass, it can easily tolerate.

In time, hop bitterness removable and sweetness will dominate. In about 2 years, Stout be an exciting companion to a strong chocolate cake!

Save a box, forget it and enjoy! But do not wait too long. by saving it dark and cool, it is not unlikely that it will keep for years.
